properties.media:imagetext:
Bixby, Manila
- 2 -
October 15, 1937
it is something to be considered.
It is on this basis, although frankly
we are both very skeptical (and I, characteristically, more so
than he)
that he approved your undertaking.
I am much relieved to note from your letter that you feel
there is very slight personal danger involved in your going to Manking,
and I hope you are not unduly optimistic.
I don't think the chances of
success are such as to warrant either you or Bond running any risks
whatever,
sure, in spite of what you say, that there must be
a considerable risk. I shall feel much relieved when I hear you have
come out again.
You refer in your letter to the fact that CNAC needs
direction, spare parts,
new equipment, and new motors.
With regard to
the first item I an a bit non-plussed as to what you are going to find
left to direct.
It is true there are
two DC-2*s, and possibly
another if we can send over the new fuselage from the
Douglas factory,
that you are going to have to operste with three American pilots--and
the nost recent acquisitions of CNAC and evidently,
from their
willingness to continue operating through the recent disturbances, very
much of the "barnstorming"
type.
In other words, the best and most re-
liable pilots have gone out of the picture for good.
You also say
that
our prize Chinese pilot, Donald kong, has quit and the othere are definite-
ly not up to DC-2 operations.
If you have Wilke and Larsen available,
maintenance may improve but I wonder if they have adequate facilities at
the bases where they will need to operate, and they certainly must be in
need of spare
parts, etc.
This brings me to the second question, which is,
we going to get new spare
parts, new motors,
and other new equipnent which
CNAC may buy,
presumably with funds advanced by the Government, into China?
It begins to look now as though neutrality legislation would not be in-
voked, and so we can probably
continue to make shipments without any legal
difficulties,
but the physical difficulties are going to be enormous.
do not see the possibility of shipping into Shanghai
for a long time
come and I understand that boate which have to stop at Japanese ports,
and others as well, are refusing shipments which can be classed as muni-
tions, even if consigned to Hong Kong.
Pasco is quite willing
but I think one of the first problems for you and Bond to settle will
to advise us of the nethod by which we can make or at least try
shipment of spare parts for CNAC, not only with assurance of delivery
but with assurance that we will be paid.
The President was quite upset when he realized that the
DC-2 had been flown away from Hong Kong after settling the Texas 011 clan
but without paying us anything.
Unfortunately I had assured him that we
were going to hold that plane until we atleast got the $100,000 Mexican
with balance promised, which program he reluctantly approved. I see you
dAEOLISIPIO
